oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wright, John. Socwatsha Kaphaphu, James Stuart, and Their Conversations on the Past, 1897-1922. Kronos 41, no. 1 (2015), 142-65.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Wright, John. Socwatsha Kaphaphu, James Stuart, and Their Conversations on the Past, 1897-1922. Kronos 41, no. 1 (2015), 142-65.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights:
Creative Commons License: CC BY-NC-ND
https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/3.0/

oai_dc:dc.dc:source: [Source - Wright, John. Socwatsha Kaphaphu, James Stuart, and Their Conversations on the Past, 1897-1922. Kronos 41, no. 1 (2015), 142-65.] [Abstract: From 1897 to 1922, through all the phases of his career as a researcher into the histories and customs of Africans in Zululand and Natal, the colonial official James Stuart made copious notes of his ongoing conversations with Socwatsha kaPhaphu. Renderings of these notes fill 168 printed pages of volume 6 of the James Stuart Archive, published in 2014. The notes not only form a rich source of empirical historical information but also give insights into the contexts in which knowledges of the past were made and circulated in African societies in Zululand and Natal in the first two decades of the twentieth century. In addition, they reveal something of Stuart's own methods as a recorder of oral histories, and the changing conditions in which he worked. This essay examines the scope and, where possible, the sources of Socwatshas knowledge of the past, and why and when Stuart engaged in recording particular aspects of it. In doing so, the essay points up the inescapable intertwinings of accounts of the past as narrated by an African commentator and as recorded in writing by a colonial official. Scholars are now examining in detail the roles played by African knowledge makers in the making and circulating of literary knowledges of the continent in the colonial era; this essay takes a further step in this direction.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: fhya-depot
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Socwatsha kaPhaphu, James Stuart, and Their Conversations on the Past, 1897-1922

[Source - Ettore Morelli for FHYA, 2020: A digitised copy of the book published by the French missionary Thomas Arbousset in 1846, being the first translation in English of the 1842 French edition. This edition did not include lithographies and it is unclear if it included the map; this copy does not include the map.]

[Source - Ettore Morelli for FHYA, 2020: A digitised copy of the book published by the French missionary Thomas Arbousset in 1842, covering the travels he and Francois Daumas undertook in 1836 in the regions surrounding the Caledon Valley, in modern Lesotho and Free State Province. The book was first published in French. This edition contains lithographies and a map; this digital copy does not include the map and some pages are missing. No complete copy has been found online yet.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:source: [Source - Ettore Morelli for FHYA, 2020: A digitised copy of the book published by the French missionary Eugene Casalis when back from his evangelical fieldwork in modern Lesotho. The book was published during the wars between Lesotho and the Republic of the Orange Free State and advocated for the independence of the Basotho of Moshoeshoe. The book is roughly divided into a narrative of the arrival of the missionaries and a ethnographical description of the Basotho. The book contains lithographies and a map, included in this digital copy.]
